definition: morning and evening visits to parents/cf 昏定晨省[hun1 ding4 chen2 xing3]
morning/dawn/daybreak
muddle-headed/twilight/to faint/to lose consciousness
to set/to fix/to determine/to decide/to order
to inspect/to examine/to be aware/to pay a visit (to one's parents or elders)
to save/to economize/to do without/to omit/to leave out/province/(archaic) central government department
to pay respects/to wish good health/in Qing times, a specific form of salutation (see also 打千[da3 qian1])
to pay one's respects/to give regards to
husband's father
(old) dowager/old lady (title for the mother of a noble or an official)
maids and concubines
to serve/to wait upon
the females in a family/womenfolk
husband's father and mother
wife of mother's brother/aunt/maternal uncle's wife
maternal aunt/father's concubine (old)
first return of bride to her parental home
seeing to bed in the evening and visiting in the morning (ancient filial duty)
to answer the roll call at 卯時|卯时[mao3 shi2], i.e. between 5 and 7 am/fig. to put in a conventional appearance
to observe mourning for one's parents
wives of brothers/sisters-in-law
to attend to/to care for (patients etc)/to look after/to wait upon/to serve/also written 伏侍, see also 服事[fu2 shi4]
